mainMenu.astronautReply: Greetings, space explorer! How can I assist you today?

aboutInterstellix.astronautReply: Interstellix is your portal to cosmic history! We bring you real astronomical events that happened on any given date throughout time. From launches to discoveries, it's all here.

eventsToday.astronautReply: Let me check the archives for today's date...

whoAreYou.astronautReply: I am Astro, your AI companion aboard the Interstellix. My purpose is to guide you through the vastness of space history.

spaceFact.astronautReply: Here's a cosmic fact for you:

allSpaceFacts: Did you know that a day on Venus is longer than its year? It takes Venus 243 Earth days to rotate once on its axis, but only 225 Earth days to orbit the Sun!
The largest known structure in the universe is the Hercules-Corona Borealis Great Wall, a massive filament of galaxies stretching over 10 billion light-years across.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth. That's a lot of stars!
Neutron stars are so dense that a single teaspoon of their material would weigh about 6 billion tons.
The Sun is actually a yellow dwarf star, and it's just one of over 100 billion stars in our Milky Way galaxy.

spaceJoke.astronautReply: Ready for a laugh? Here's a space joke:

allSpaceJokes: Why did the sun go to school? To get brighter!
What do you call a lazy kangaroo in space? Pouch potato!
How do you organize a space party? You planet!
What do you call a space alien who likes to garden? A terra-former!
Why did the astronaut break up with the astronomer? He needed space!

astronautReply: Phew‚Ä¶ that was close. I lost comms for a while.
The oxygen stabilizer is back online ‚Äî thanks to you.
You just saved this mission. I owe you one.

The system experienced a critical power surge, causing a temporary blackout in our navigation and life support. Your quick action in the terminal rerouted auxiliary power, preventing a full system collapse.
From now on, you can always access me by clicking the floating astronaut icon in the bottom-left corner of your screen. I'm here to assist you with any cosmic queries!

postRecoveryOptions.astronautReply: What would you like to do next, Commander?

fullMainMenu.astronautReply: Welcome back, Commander! How can I assist you further?

recoveredLogbook.astronautReply: The logbook contains records of all our past missions and discoveries. It's a treasure trove of information!

continueExploring.astronautReply: Excellent! The cosmos awaits. Feel free to use the date picker to explore any date in space history.

missionBriefing.astronautReply: Our current mission is to document and share every significant event in space history. Your role is crucial in navigating these archives.
